It should be noted that the "Single Neuron Solution" to the double pole b=
alancing without velocities has been "discovered" by a number of other TWEA=
Ns before NEAT, my own system amongst them, that is if the Physics Simulati=
on is correct and the specifications for the agreed solution are the same.
=

What is considered a solution? 
1. A NN that can balance the poles for 100=
000timesteps of 0.02s, and pass the generalization test with a score over 2=
00?
OR
2. A NN that can balance the poles for 1000 time steps of 0.02s, and=
 pas the generalization test with a score over 200?


--- In neat@yahoogrou=
ps.com, "Ken" <kstanley@...> wrote:
>
> 
> 
> I also gave this answer to Ge=
ne in email, but I wanted to answer here as well for others that may be cur=
ious:
> 
> In fact, there is a solution to the no-velocity version that has=
 only a single hidden neuron.  In fact, there is a solution with no hidden =
neurons (which must have a recurrent connection on the output).  The pole b=
alancing tasks turned out to require much less structure than was thought, =
which is something NEAT discovered.
> 
> ken
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.c=
om, "genemerdock" <genemerdock@> wrote:
> >
> > I'm experiencing some stran=
ge behavior from NEAT, I've rewritten the Double Pole Without Velocities an=
d with Damping recently using another language, and plugged it back in. 
> =
> 
> > After running the experiment many times, every once in a rare while =
NEAT manages to solve the Double Pole Balancing without velocities and with=
 Damping experiment using 1 Neuron. Is the 1 Neuron solution possible, or h=
ave I made a mistake somewhere while rewriting the experiment.
> >
>
